author: yorickdowne
content: I know it’s not the most pressing thing, and, it’s difficult for solo stakers to test their rigs. Can this be added to an upcoming ACD to discuss whether to either do a state change and create 4 trillion or so GoETH and possibly change forced exit amount to 31, from 16; or spin up a new testnet with ERC-20 deposit contract, and also consider changing amount at which forced exit happens.

author: jgm
content: Bear in mind that providing practically unlimited goerli Ether creates a "nothing at stake" problem, where it would be easy for someone to grief the network by creating lots of validators and then "owning" the consensus side of things (it would take some time for them to ramp up with the entry queue, but they could start by flooding it with validators and so stop any others from creating validators of their own).

author: parithosh
content:
How's the ethstaker facuet been with brightID? Do you think if we fund it sufficiently, it'll help alleviate the problem for a while?

I agree that inflating goerli supply and funding every faucet will just lead to chaos, we'd need to inflate the supply and still be careful about where the supply ends up. But atleast we can be more liberal with the funds and try out more things.

author: jgm
content: Unlimited Ether plus gated deposit contract seems to be the best compromise, but that would require a new chain (or changes to CL logic).

author: djrtwo
content:
I suggest maybe doing a testnet that resets every four to eight weeks on a known cycle. A know end of life each time. Faucets can be a bit more liberal because (1) if it gets messed up, its not terrible and (2) the hording of testnet eth is less rational because the testnet was built to be soon destroyed

This could be a good place to test validator setups

That said, I think someone else needs to lead the charge. There seems to be little appetite from devs to support another testnet and this would require additional automation to do the scheduled build and tear down

author: parithosh
content:
That would be the most straightforward approach, but we'd definitely need to find a group of people willing to do this. 

Additionally, if the testnet isn't a standard supported one - neither would launchpad or the staking-cli support it.  So you quickly diverge from the mainnet staking direction, meaning it isn't a useful enough testnet to simulate the full experience.

author: yorickdowne
content:
BrightID and now gitcoin passport keep farmers out - they also create quite the hurdle, as BrightID’s tech fails on the regular.
Fingers crossed the new passport option makes this easier for people.

author: remyroy
content: Our faucet is doing well, but it's a pain for potential stakers who need to pass all these barriers. It creates a lot of support requests and some abandon midway. I think an irregular state change that would inflate Goerli supply by many orders of magnitude coupled with a much higher `EJECTION_BALANCE` would be ideal. Tooling would stay the same mostly. No need to update or change the launchpad, staking-deposit-cli or clients much (besides the `EJECTION_BALANCE` network config on clients). *Nothing at stake* would still remain an issue which does not seem to have any easy solution.

author: remyroy
content: The current Goerli network also has the *Nothing at stake* issue. It simply has not been exploited yet maybe because it's somewhat difficult to get any large amount of GoETH. You would need around 12.3M GoETH to gain a 51% validator share. It would be quite visible and it would take months before all these validators would be activated. I'm guessing some kind of Goerli fork would be coordinated in time if it were to happen now. Maybe that solution would be good enough as well for a Goerli network that has a very large GoETH supply.

author: parithosh
content:
The issue with having too "simple" faucets seem to be that they get drained. It was a pain to maintain the kiln faucet cause bots drained it constantly, even though there was 0 incentive to. People will inevitably hoard goerli eth if its made too easy to have, leading back to the exact situation we're in right now. 

That's the main reason I'm in favor of inflating the supply but still gating access. The increased ejection balance is a great idea, we should do that irrespective of what solution we go with.

author: remyroy
content: Our faucet is not in the "simple" kind. Even with a larger supply, we could keep it somewhat hard to request GoETH. The only public faucets remaining on Goerli are either in the "hard" kind or in the kind that give 0.01 GoETH.

author: parithosh
content:
What sort of faucet do you imagine working that is easier than the current ethstaker one but enough to deter bots? 

I'd vote for making sure the ethstaker faucet is well funded as a stop gap(especially if you think that'll help or make experimentation easier) until we have a more permanent solution.

Also it isn't much, but if you give me the ethstaker faucet address, I can set that as the fee recipient address for the EF goerli validators.

author: remyroy
content:
It's always a tech war and a balancing act between bot and legitimate user requests. There is no perfect solution only compromises. I like the approach of giving users multiple ways of proving they are not sybils or that they have a legitimate purpose. We might implement more ways in the future. It's also a good opportunity for us to do A/B testing and see which way is better in terms of user experience, preventing sybils, less support involved, etc.

Our current faucet address is `0x4D496CcC28058B1D74B7a19541663E21154f9c84`.

author: parithosh
content:
Have you guys tried out performing deposits on behalf of the users? So they give you the deposit data and you do the final transaction? 

Any idea what number of users request eth and setup validators every month?

Great, I'll set it during the next round of updates.

author: remyroy
content: We have both ways. Our direct deposit is less restricted but the user experience is less interesting as well. It's more complicated and it differs from the full experience someone can expect on Mainnet. We still keep it because it's another alternative that some users like.

author: remyroy
content: In the last month, we provided deposits or transfers for around 650 validators on Goerli.
